keyTakeAways: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) delayed formal approval of the Net Zero Framework (NZF) by at least 12 months due to threats from U.S. President Donald Trump.
Trump publicly condemned the IMO's plan as a 'Global Green New Scam Tax' and threatened sanctions, visa restrictions, and port levies on supporting countries.
The decision to delay was made after a hastily arranged vote in London, with 57 members voting in favor of postponement and 49 against.
The Net Zero Framework would have been the first global carbon-pricing system for shipping, imposing a $380 penalty per metric tonne of excess CO2-equivalent emissions.
The IMO's goal is to reduce net emissions from shipping by 20% by 2030 and eliminate them by 2050.
Countries like China, the EU, Britain, and Brazil supported the framework, while Russia and Saudi Arabia opposed it.
Argentina and Singapore, previously supportive, voted to postpone the adoption this week.
The International Chamber of Shipping expressed concern over lack of clarity, stressing the need for investment in decarbonization.
Vanuatu’s climate minister called the delay 'unacceptable' given accelerating climate change and emphasized international legal standing.
Climate change is already affecting shipping through altered ocean currents and more frequent storms, increasing safety risks.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) postponed the formal adoption of its Net Zero Framework (NZF) by at least 12 months after U.S. President Donald Trump threatened sanctions on countries supporting the plan, which would have introduced a global carbon-pricing system charging ships $380 per metric tonne of excess CO2 emissions. The decision, made during a London meeting, follows Trump's public condemnation of the initiative as a 'Global Green New Scam Tax' and his call for countries to vote against it. While 63 countries previously supported the framework, key supporters such as China, the EU, and Britain were pressured, and countries like Argentina and Singapore changed their stance. The delay undermines global efforts to reduce shipping emissions, with the IMO aiming for a 20% cut by 2030 and full elimination by 2050. Climate scientists and maritime industry leaders warn that this setback threatens progress against climate change, with rising storms and altered ocean currents already impacting shipping safety. Despite opposition from fossil fuel-aligned nations, the framework remains a critical step toward sustainable maritime transport.
title: Trump torpedoes international deal to reduce shipping emissions
